name: Photoacoustic Tomography / Optoacoustic Tomography
summary: Photoacoustic tomography (PAT), also called optoacoustic tomography (OAT), is a hybrid imaging technique combining optical excitation with ultrasonic detection to generate 3D images of optical absorption contrast within turbid media. Pulsed laser light (ns-scale, typically NIR 700-1200 nm) illuminates the sample; absorbed photons generate localized transient heating (mK rise); thermoelastic expansion launches broadband ultrasonic waves (MHz frequencies) that propagate to the surface where an array of ultrasound transducers detects them. Time-of-flight of acoustic signals encodes depth; computational reconstruction algorithms (filtered back-projection, time-reversal, model-based) convert acoustic waveforms into 3D maps of optical absorption coefficient. PAT achieves optical contrast (molecular specificity: hemoglobin, melanin, lipids via spectral unmixing) with ultrasound resolution (100 μm - 1 mm) and penetration depth (mm to cm, exceeding pure optical imaging limited by scattering), and is emerging as a powerful tool for non-invasive subsurface imaging of cultural heritage objects.
keyApplications: Subsurface layer visualization in paintings (underdrawing, pentimenti 0.5-5 mm deep)
3D pigment distribution mapping (polychrome sculpture, painted wood, multi-layer paint)
Internal structure imaging (wood panels: growth rings, cracks, insect damage without sectioning)
Moisture/consolidant distribution (depth-resolved maps of treatments in porous materials)
Hidden text/drawings (manuscripts, palimpsests: iron-gall ink absorption contrast)
Authentication (detect modern materials with characteristic NIR absorption beneath surface)
destructiveness: non-destructive (pulsed laser with mJ-scale energy and ns pulses; operated below damage thresholds for heritage materials)
portability: primarily benchtop; early cart-mounted and prototype portable systems (50–100 kg) emerging for in-situ use
typicalTimePerMeasurement: Seconds to minutes for a single 2D slice; 1–30 minutes or more for a full 3D volume depending on field-of-view, step size, and averaging

costRange.instrument: $200,000–$1,000,000 (research PAT system: pulsed laser $100–300k + ultrasound array $50–200k + DAQ and reconstruction workstation)
costRange.perSample: $500–$2,000 per detailed 3D imaging session (including staff time and amortized equipment costs)

fundamentalPhysics.principle: Photoacoustic tomography exploits the photoacoustic effect for volumetric imaging. A short laser pulse (typically 5–10 ns) is delivered to a turbid medium. Absorbed photons raise the local temperature by ΔT in the μK–mK range. Under stress confinement (pulse duration much shorter than the acoustic transit time across the absorber), this rapid heating causes thermoelastic expansion and launches a broadband ultrasonic pressure wave. The initial pressure rise p_0 is proportional to the product of the local absorption coefficient μ_a, the optical fluence Φ, and the Grüneisen parameter Γ (which encodes the medium’s thermoelastic properties). These waves propagate outward at the sound speed c_s with minimal scattering compared to photons. An array of ultrasound detectors records the time-resolved pressure p(r⃗_d, t) at many positions. Reconstruction algorithms (e.g. filtered back-projection, time-reversal, iterative model-based inversion) solve the inverse problem p(r⃗_d, t) → p_0(r⃗) → μ_a(r⃗), yielding a 3D map of optical absorption.
fundamentalPhysics.physicalPhenomenon: Unlike purely optical imaging, where multiple scattering scrambles photon paths and limits depth resolution, PAT converts optical absorption into acoustic waves that travel ballistically through soft, weakly attenuating media. This gives optical contrast (sensitive to chromophore absorption spectra: pigments, inks, binders) while inheriting the centimeter-scale penetration and spatial resolution of ultrasound. In heritage contexts, PAT can reveal carbon-based underdrawings beneath highly scattering or absorbing paint layers (e.g., lead white impasto), map pigment distributions in three dimensions, and visualize hidden structural features in wood and other turbid substrates.

interactionDepth.description: The usable imaging depth in PAT is governed by both optical and acoustic propagation. Optical penetration determines how deeply sufficient fluence reaches to excite absorbers, while acoustic propagation and detection determine how far the generated waves can travel back to the detectors with acceptable SNR. In turbid heritage materials (paints, wood, textiles), NIR wavelengths (700–1000 nm) offer a compromise between absorption and scattering, giving optical penetration on the order of 1–10 mm. Ultrasound in soft, low-loss media can propagate over centimeters, so in most heritage cases the optical transport is the limiting factor. Practical PAT imaging of paintings and polychrome objects typically achieves 0.5–10 mm depth, with deeper imaging (up to ~20 mm) possible in relatively transparent media like some woods.

materialSpecific.opticalPenetration: ≈1–5 mm at 700–900 nm, strongly dependent on pigment loading and scattering
materialSpecific.practicalDepth: ≈1–5 mm (optically limited; suitable for underdrawing and hidden layers in paintings)

materialSpecific.opticalPenetration: ≈5–20 mm in NIR (wood can be relatively transparent compared to dense paints)
materialSpecific.practicalDepth: ≈5–20 mm (optically limited; enables internal structure and defect imaging)
≈10–30 mm (useful for subsurface features in layered textiles)

materialSpecific.material: Dense, highly absorbing pigment layers (e.g., lead white, vermilion)
materialSpecific.opticalPenetration: ≈0.5–2 mm (strong scattering and absorption in NIR)
materialSpecific.practicalDepth: ≈0.5–2 mm (optical attenuation dominates; underlayers deeper than a few mm may be invisible)

spatialResolution.lateral: Typically 100 μm to 1 mm, determined primarily by the acoustic wavelength and aperture. Higher ultrasound frequency (e.g., 10–20 MHz) yields finer lateral resolution (~100 μm) but reduces penetration due to increased attenuation; lower frequencies (1–5 MHz) provide coarser resolution (0.5–1 mm) but allow deeper imaging.
spatialResolution.depth: Axial (depth) resolution is set by the detector bandwidth and the temporal sampling of the acoustic waveforms. For broadband transducers with 5–10 MHz bandwidth, axial resolutions on the order of 50–200 μm are typical. In many systems the axial resolution exceeds the lateral resolution.
limitingFactors: Ultrasound center frequency and bandwidth (higher frequencies and broader bandwidth improve resolution but reduce penetration)
Transducer aperture and viewing angle (limited-view geometries reduce effective lateral resolution and introduce artifacts)
Sound speed inhomogeneity (spatial variations in c_s cause phase aberrations and depth distortions if not modeled)
Signal bandwidth truncation (bandpass filtering and detector response shape the effective PSF)
Sampling density (scan step size and angular coverage must satisfy Nyquist criteria for accurate reconstruction)

sensitivity.detectionLimits: For typical heritage PAT systems, absorption coefficients on the order of μ_a ≈ 0.01–0.1 cm⁻¹ can be detected at shallow depths, while strongly absorbing pigments (μ_a ≈ 10–100 cm⁻¹) are easily visible several millimeters beneath the surface. This corresponds to pigment volume fractions down to ~0.1–1 wt% for strongly absorbing species, depending on fluence, bandwidth, and averaging.
sensitivity.dynamicRange: Effective dynamic range on the order of 10³–10⁴ in absorption, allowing simultaneous visualization of strongly absorbing pigments and weaker organic features (e.g., binders or low-concentration inks) within the same volume, especially when multi-wavelength acquisitions are used.
sensitivity.signalToNoise: Surface and shallow features can exhibit SNR of 20–100:1 per voxel under typical fluence and averaging. SNR decreases with depth due to optical and acoustic attenuation; at depths of several millimeters, SNR may drop to ~10–20:1, requiring more averaging or reduced resolution scans for robust detection.

source.type: Nanosecond pulsed laser, commonly Nd:YAG (1064 nm fundamental, 532 nm second harmonic) with optical parametric oscillator (OPO) for 700–1200 nm tuning, or Ti:sapphire and high-power diode/diode-pumped lasers for compact systems.
source.specifications: Pulse duration: 5–10 ns (ensuring stress confinement for efficient photoacoustic generation). Repetition rate: typically 10–50 Hz for Q-switched solid-state lasers, up to kHz for newer diode-based PAT systems. Wavelength range: 700–1200 nm (near-infrared window, balancing penetration and absorption contrast); 800–900 nm is common for heritage materials. Pulse energy: ~10–100 mJ at the laser output, often 1–20 mJ delivered to the object after beam delivery optics. Fluence at the sample is kept below heritage-safe limits (typically 5–20 mJ/cm², well below ANSI Z136.1 MPE where possible).
source.energyRange: Photon energies ~1.0–1.8 eV for 1200–700 nm; some systems allow extension to visible or short-wave IR via OPOs.
source.powerRange: Peak powers in the MW range during nanosecond pulses, but low average power (≤ a few watts) due to low duty cycle.

detector.type: Ultrasound transducer arrays: (1) linear arrays (e.g., 128–256 elements, 5–10 MHz center frequency) for 2D slice imaging with mechanical translation; (2) curvilinear or hemispherical arrays with hundreds to thousands of elements for true 3D PAT; (3) single focused transducers scanned mechanically for lower-cost systems.
detector.spectralRange: Typical center frequencies 1–20 MHz with fractional bandwidths of 50–100%, covering ~0.5–30 MHz. Higher frequencies provide better resolution but smaller penetration depth.
detector.efficiency: Sensitivity characterized by voltage response per unit pressure (tens of mV/MPa) and noise-equivalent pressure on the order of tens to hundreds of pascals, depending on preamplifier and averaging.
detector.timeResolution: Digitizers sample at 20–100 MHz to resolve microsecond-scale acoustic transients; timing jitter between laser trigger and acquisition must be kept below ~10 ns to maintain depth accuracy on the order of tens of micrometers.

components: Pulsed laser (Nd:YAG with OPO or Ti:sapphire / diode-based source)
Beam delivery optics or fiber bundles to homogenize and deliver a broad illumination spot (5–50 mm diameter) to the sample surface
Ultrasound transducer array (linear, arc, or hemispherical) mounted in a water tank or behind an acoustic coupling membrane
Coupling medium (degassed water or ultrasound gel) to provide efficient acoustic transmission between object and transducers
High-speed multi-channel data acquisition system (tens to hundreds of channels at 20–100 MHz sampling rates)
Motion stages for scanning the transducer or sample (in linear-array or single-element systems)
Control and reconstruction workstation (often with GPU acceleration for time-reversal and iterative algorithms)
opticalSystem.beamPath: The pulsed laser beam is expanded or delivered via a fiber bundle to illuminate the region of interest on the object. Absorbed light generates broadband acoustic waves that propagate through the object and coupling medium to the ultrasound transducers, which convert pressure into electrical signals. These signals are digitized and subsequently processed and reconstructed into a 3D absorption map.
opticalSystem.focusing: In most PAT systems the optical beam is weakly focused or made quasi-uniform to avoid hot spots and to maximize penetration. Acoustic focusing is achieved either by the inherent focus of single-element transducers or, more commonly, via synthetic focusing (beamforming and time-reversal) using array data.

criticalComponents: Pulsed laser with appropriate wavelength range, pulse duration, and energy (dominant cost and safety driver)
Ultrasound transducer array with sufficient element count, bandwidth, and sensitivity
High-speed, multi-channel DAQ with stable, low-jitter triggering
Acoustic coupling arrangement (water bath or gel/membrane) that is compatible with heritage materials
Robust and well-validated reconstruction software (FBP, time-reversal, or model-based) with appropriate sound-speed modeling
instrumentation.typicalConfiguration: A representative heritage PAT setup might use a 1064 nm Nd:YAG laser pumping an OPO tuned to 800–900 nm (10 ns pulses, 10–20 Hz, 50–80 mJ per pulse), a 128-element linear ultrasound array with 5 MHz center frequency and ~70% fractional bandwidth, a water-coupling tank or gel-membrane interface above the painting or object, and a motorized XY stage to scan the array over a 50×50 mm region in 0.5–1 mm steps. Data are acquired with a 128-channel 40–60 MHz DAQ (e.g., Verasonics Vantage) and reconstructed using the k-Wave MATLAB toolbox running on a GPU-enabled workstation. A typical 50×50×5 mm³ volume with ~100–200 μm axial resolution and ~300–500 μm lateral sampling can be acquired in tens of minutes to a few hours, depending on averaging.

facilityRequirements.space: An optical table or rigid lab bench with roughly 1.5×2 m footprint is needed for the laser, beam delivery optics, coupling tank, transducer array, and motion stages. Additional space is required for the laser power supply, chiller (if needed), and reconstruction workstation.
utilities: Mains power: 110/230 VAC with ~20–30 A capacity for the laser, DAQ, and computing hardware
Cooling water for the laser (if using water-cooled pump chambers or chillers), typically 1–2 L/min
Compressed air or vacuum for some positioning and safety systems (optional)
Supply of degassed or deionized water and/or ultrasound gel for acoustic coupling
environmental: Temperature stability within ±2 °C to maintain laser pointing, energy stability, and accurate knowledge of sound speed in the coupling medium
Controlled access and laser safety measures appropriate for Class 4 lasers (interlocks, beam enclosures, warning lights, safety eyewear)

Low acoustic and mechanical vibration is beneficial but PAT is relatively tolerant compared to interferometric techniques; major concern is mechanical stability of the sample and transducer during long scans

commercialSystems.specifications: Tunable OPO-pumped Nd:YAG laser (680–980 nm), 10 Hz repetition rate, 256-element arc-shaped ultrasound array, designed for small-animal imaging but adaptable to flat samples such as panels and paintings.
Tunable laser (700–900 nm), multi-element arc array, 3D optoacoustic tomography with dedicated reconstruction software; primarily for biomedical research.

Component-based systems using commercial lasers and ultrasound arrays (e.g., Nd:YAG + OPO with clinical or custom arrays), combined with open-source reconstruction (k-Wave) and custom mechanical stages; tailored to specific heritage objects and constraints.
commercialSystems.approximateCost: $200,000–$500,000 (components and integration; no commercial off-the-shelf heritage PAT system as of 2025)

samplePreparation.sampleSize: Intact objects such as paintings and polychrome panels up to tens of centimeters across can be imaged; field-of-view is typically 5–200 mm depending on array size and scan range. Thicknesses up to several centimeters are accessible in wood and low-attenuation media, though practical heritage work often focuses on the first 1–2 cm from the surface.
samplePreparation.mountingProcedure: The object is mounted securely on a support or positioning stage, usually with the region of interest oriented toward the transducer array. For water-immersion setups, the object (or a portion of it) is placed in a sealed holder or tank filled with degassed water; for moisture-sensitive works, a thin transparent membrane with ultrasound gel may be used to provide acoustic coupling while protecting the surface from direct contact with water. Vibrational stability is important during long scans to avoid blurring.
samplePreparation.surfacePreparation: No invasive surface preparation is required. However, loosely bound dust and particulates should be gently removed to avoid spurious surface absorption and to prevent contamination of the coupling medium. Highly reflective or absorbing surface coatings (e.g., metallic foils, thick black overpaints) may need to be characterized in advance, as they can dominate the photoacoustic signal and obscure deeper features.
contaminationConcerns: Water or gel ingress into porous or unprotected substrates (canvas, unvarnished wood) must be carefully controlled; barriers (films, consolidants) or non-contact all-optical detection can mitigate risk.
Strongly absorbing surface contaminants (e.g., soot, surface grime) can produce intense superficial signals that overshadow deeper absorbers; cleaning or careful interpretation may be required.
Repeated high-fluence illumination of highly photosensitive materials (fugitive dyes, degraded binders) can induce photochemical or photomechanical damage if safety limits are exceeded.

steps.title: System setup, safety check, and calibration
steps.description: Power up the laser, DAQ, and motion control systems. Perform laser warm-up (15–30 minutes) and verify output energy and beam quality at the working wavelength (e.g., 800 nm). Confirm that all laser safety interlocks and beam enclosures are functional, and ensure all personnel wear appropriate eye protection. Calibrate the ultrasound system using a simple phantom (e.g., a point absorber or pencil lead in agar) to verify timing, sound speed, and basic resolution. Adjust the assumed sound speed in the reconstruction software until the reconstructed depth of the phantom matches its known physical position.
criticalParameters: Laser pulse energy stability (variations <10% over the scan to avoid intensity banding)
Accurate synchronization between laser trigger and DAQ sampling (timing jitter <10 ns)
Correct sound speed setting for the coupling medium and object (within ~5% of true value)

steps.title: Sample positioning and acoustic coupling
steps.description: Position the object so that the region of interest is within the transducer field-of-view. For water immersion, fill the coupling tank with degassed water and carefully remove air bubbles from the object surface and transducer face. For gel/membrane coupling, apply a uniform layer of ultrasound gel to the membrane, gently press it against the object surface, and check for trapped air. Use test ultrasound pulses or low-energy photoacoustic shots to confirm that strong, consistent signals are detected across the array.
criticalParameters: Absence of air gaps between the object and the coupling medium (air blocks ultrasound)
Stable mechanical contact or immersion throughout the planned scan duration
Avoiding excessive pressure on fragile surfaces (use soft membranes and minimal contact force)

steps.title: Pilot acquisition and parameter optimization
steps.description: Acquire a small pilot dataset (e.g., a single B-scan or a small 2D grid) to check signal levels, SNR, and potential artifacts. Adjust laser fluence to remain within safe limits while achieving adequate SNR (typically ≥20:1 for key features). Optimize the choice of wavelength based on expected absorbers: for carbon-based underdrawing, ~750–850 nm is often effective; for metal-based pigments or binders, consider scanning several wavelengths to identify optimal contrast. Tune DAQ settings (gain, sampling rate, number of averages) to balance SNR and acquisition time.
criticalParameters: Maintaining fluence within heritage-safe limits (preferably below 10–20 mJ/cm²)
Ensuring sufficient SNR for both shallow and deeper features (adjust averaging if needed)
Selecting wavelengths that maximize contrast for target materials while preserving penetration

steps.title: 3D volume acquisition
steps.description: Define the scan geometry and sampling grid (e.g., a 2D raster of transducer positions over the region of interest, or a set of angular views if using a rotating or arcuate array). For each position or view, fire the laser and record the full set of time-resolved RF signals from all transducer elements. Optionally average multiple laser shots per position to improve SNR, taking care to monitor cumulative fluence on the object. Document all acquisition parameters (laser energy, wavelength, repetition rate, transducer model, sampling rate, scan geometry, coupling method) in metadata.
steps.duration: 30 minutes to several hours depending on FOV, step size, and averaging
criticalParameters: Adequate spatial sampling (step sizes compatible with the system’s lateral resolution and Nyquist criteria)
Stable fluence and system response over the full acquisition
Sufficient averaging for deeper or weakly absorbing features without exceeding acceptable dose

steps.title: Multi-wavelength (spectroscopic) PAT (optional)
steps.description: For spectroscopic PAT, repeat the 3D acquisition at several wavelengths chosen to sample the absorption spectra of expected chromophores (e.g., carbon black, vermilion, ultramarine, binders). For each wavelength, measure and record the delivered fluence to enable normalization. After reconstructing volumes at each wavelength, perform spectral unmixing to estimate the spatial distribution of individual chromophores using reference spectra or library data.
steps.duration: Multiplicative factor of the single-wavelength scan time (e.g., 3–10× longer for 3–10 wavelengths)
criticalParameters: Accurate wavelength calibration and stable tuning of the laser/OPO
Consistent fluence normalization across wavelengths
Appropriate selection of wavelengths to resolve overlapping pigment spectra

steps.title: Reconstruction and quality assurance
steps.description: Transfer the raw RF data to the reconstruction workstation and perform preprocessing (bandpass filtering, time-gain compensation, bad-channel removal, and optional averaging). Choose and apply an appropriate reconstruction algorithm: filtered back-projection for rapid preview and qualitative assessment; time-reversal or iterative model-based methods for higher-quality, artifact-reduced volumes. Inspect reconstructed slices and maximum-intensity projections to verify that known test objects or features appear at the expected locations and depths. Adjust reconstruction parameters (sound speed, grid spacing, regularization strength) as needed.
steps.duration: 10 minutes to several hours depending on volume size and algorithm
criticalParameters: Accurate sound-speed model (single value or spatial map for heterogeneous materials)
Sufficient grid resolution to capture the system’s spatial bandwidth
Detection and mitigation of reconstruction artifacts (limited-view streaks, rings, depth distortions)

steps.title: Visualization, interpretation, and integration with other modalities
steps.description: Visualize the reconstructed volume using slice displays, maximum intensity projections, and 3D volume rendering. Identify subsurface features such as underdrawings, pentimenti, internal cracks, or pigment stratigraphy. Where possible, co-register PAT volumes with other imaging data (visible/IR reflectography, X-radiography, MA-XRF, OCT) using shared fiducial markers or anatomical/structural landmarks. Use these combined datasets to interpret the physical and material structure of the object, to guide sampling, and to support conservation decision-making.
steps.duration: 30 minutes to several hours per dataset
criticalParameters: Accurate co-registration with complementary modalities
Careful discrimination between true subsurface features and reconstruction artifacts
Clear documentation of interpretation uncertainties and limitations for conservation reports

operatingParameters.notes: Near-infrared window favored for heritage PAT; 750–900 nm is often optimal for carbon-based underdrawing and many common pigments while preserving depth penetration.

operatingParameters.range: 1–20 mJ (at the object) depending on beam size and safety constraints
operatingParameters.notes: Fluence typically limited to 5–20 mJ/cm² to avoid photothermal or photomechanical damage; exact limits must follow relevant laser safety standards and material-specific testing.
Short pulses are required for stress confinement (pulse duration much shorter than the acoustic transit time across absorbing structures). Longer pulses reduce PA efficiency and axial resolution.

operatingParameters.typicalValue: 10–20 Hz for Q-switched lasers; up to kHz for diode-based systems
operatingParameters.notes: Higher repetition rates enable faster scanning but must be balanced against average power, heating, and system complexity.
Lower frequencies (1–5 MHz) favor deeper imaging with coarser resolution; higher frequencies (10–20 MHz) improve resolution (≈100 μm) but restrict penetration to a few millimeters.
Broad bandwidth improves axial resolution and allows accurate reconstruction of short pressure pulses; practical bandwidth is limited by transducer design and electronics.
Must exceed twice the highest acoustic frequency to satisfy Nyquist; oversampling improves timing precision and facilitates digital filtering.
Step size should be comparable to or smaller than half the lateral resolution (≈λ_s/2) to avoid undersampling; smaller steps improve image quality but increase acquisition time.
Averaging improves SNR by √N but increases acquisition time and total delivered energy; optimal values depend on signal strength and heritage safety constraints.

standards: Tissue- or paint-mimicking phantoms (e.g., agar or polymer gels with embedded absorbing inclusions at known depths and known μ_a and μ_s')
Point or line absorbers (pencil leads, carbon fibers) embedded at known locations to verify depth accuracy and spatial resolution
Reference absorbers with known spectra (e.g., dye or pigment solutions) for spectroscopic PAT calibration
Reflective timing targets for verifying DAQ trigger and sampling alignment
calibration.frequency: Daily checks of laser energy, wavelength, and DAQ timing; weekly or per campaign phantom imaging to verify depth accuracy and resolution; full calibration (including sound speed and system response) at the start of major studies or after hardware changes.
calibration.procedure: Acquire PAT data from a calibration phantom with known absorber positions and optical properties. Reconstruct the volume using the same parameters as for the heritage object. Compare measured depths and PSFs to the known ground truth to adjust the assumed sound speed and verify spatial resolution. Measure the laser fluence at the sample for each wavelength and incorporate this information into quantitative μ_a estimation or spectral unmixing. Document calibration results and uncertainties for traceability.

checkpoints: Verification that raw RF signals have adequate SNR and no systematic saturation or clipping
Depth measurements on phantoms agree with known geometries within the expected error (e.g., ±5–10%)
Reconstructed resolution (axial and lateral) is consistent with transducer specifications and design calculations
No significant motion artifacts or misalignment across the scanned volume
Reconstruction artifacts (streaks, rings, depth distortions) are understood and acceptable for the intended interpretation

commonArtifacts.cause: Restricted angular coverage (e.g., single linear array on one side of the object) or missing transducer elements lead to incomplete sampling of the acoustic wavefield.
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Use multiple viewing angles or curved/hemispherical arrays when possible; apply model-based or iterative reconstructions that regularize under-sampled directions; exclude or equalize poorly performing elements.

commonArtifacts.cause: High absorption in surface layers (varnish, dark overpaint) produces dominant superficial signals that can mask deeper features; multiple acoustic reflections at the coupling interface can create ghost structures.
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Time-gate early arrivals to suppress surface signals when focusing on deeper structures; choose wavelengths with reduced surface absorption; improve coupling and reduce impedance mismatches to limit ringing; interpret depth profiles in conjunction with other modalities (e.g., IRR, OCT) to identify surface contributions.

commonArtifacts.cause: Incorrect assumptions about the speed of sound (c_s) or ignoring inhomogeneities in c_s across different layers (e.g., paint vs wood).
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Measure or estimate c_s for each dominant material using phantoms or ultrasound tests; use spatially varying sound-speed maps in advanced reconstructions; quantify residual depth errors and report them in documentation.

commonArtifacts.artifact: Low penetration and missing deep features
commonArtifacts.cause: Severe optical attenuation by dense or highly scattering surface layers, or strong ultrasound attenuation at high frequencies.
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Optimize wavelength for maximum penetration (e.g., shift toward longer NIR wavelengths within safety constraints); reduce ultrasound frequency to increase depth at the cost of resolution; accept that some deep features may be beyond PAT’s depth range and consider complementary techniques (X-radiography, neutron imaging, terahertz).

commonArtifacts.cause: Mechanical drift or vibration of the object or transducer during long acquisitions.
commonArtifacts.mitigation: Mechanically stabilize the object and array; minimize scan times by optimizing step size and averaging; if necessary, use retrospective motion correction and registration between sub-volumes.

troubleshooting.cause: Laser not firing or misaligned; insufficient optical fluence at the sample; poor acoustic coupling; non-absorbing sample at chosen wavelength; DAQ mis-triggered.
troubleshooting.solution: Verify laser output and beam path with suitable sensors or viewers; confirm trigger synchronization on an oscilloscope; test the system with a known strong absorber (e.g., carbon black in water) to confirm functionality; adjust fluence and coupling before returning to the heritage object.

troubleshooting.problem: Signal present but extremely low SNR
troubleshooting.cause: Fluence too low, strong attenuation, or low absorption contrast; excessive electronic noise; inadequate averaging.
troubleshooting.solution: Increase averaging and/or modestly increase fluence while respecting safety limits; refine coupling and reduce ambient electrical noise; consider switching to a more favorable wavelength or to a lower ultrasound frequency to improve penetration.

troubleshooting.cause: Severe limited-view geometry, wrong sound-speed model, or strong heterogeneities not captured by the forward model.
troubleshooting.solution: Experiment with time-reversal or iterative reconstruction algorithms that can partially compensate for limited-view effects; incorporate more accurate sound-speed estimates; acquire additional views if feasible; validate with phantoms and cross-check against independent modalities.

fileFormats: HDF5 containers (multi-dimensional RF data + metadata, common in research PAT systems)
MATLAB MAT files (native format for k-Wave and many academic toolchains)
Proprietary DAQ formats (e.g., Verasonics data structures) with conversion scripts to open formats
Binary files plus ASCII/JSON metadata describing geometry, timing, and system parameters
rawDataFormat.dataStructure: Raw data are typically stored as arrays indexed by detector channel, time sample, and scan position or view (e.g., [nChannels × nSamples × nPositions] or [nChannels × nSamples × nX × nY]). Reconstructed data are stored as 3D volumes μ_a(x,y,z) and, for spectroscopic PAT, as 4D arrays μ_a(x,y,z,λ).
rawDataFormat.typicalFileSize: From hundreds of megabytes to many gigabytes for full 3D multi-wavelength studies (e.g., 128 channels × 4096 samples × 5000 positions × 2 bytes ≈ 5 GB of raw RF data; reconstructed volumes are typically 0.1–1 GB per wavelength).

preprocessing.description: Apply digital bandpass filters to remove low-frequency drift and high-frequency electronic noise, matching the transducer’s bandwidth (e.g., 0.5–10 MHz for a 5 MHz transducer). This improves SNR and reduces reconstruction artifacts.
preprocessing.software: MATLAB (butter, filtfilt), Python (scipy.signal), or built-in DAQ filtering modules

preprocessing.description: Because acoustic signals decay with depth due to geometric spreading and attenuation, apply a time-dependent gain function (e.g., exponential or polynomial in time) to partially equalize signal amplitudes across depth, improving visibility of deep features.
preprocessing.software: Custom scripts in MATLAB/Python or k-Wave utilities; often implemented as a multiplicative window in time.

preprocessing.description: Normalize each transducer channel by its sensitivity (measured on a homogeneous phantom) and identify dead or excessively noisy channels for removal or interpolation. This reduces ring and streak artifacts in reconstructions.
preprocessing.software: MATLAB/Python scripts using statistics (e.g., median absolute deviation) to detect outliers.

preprocessing.description: If there is shot-to-shot or channel-to-channel timing jitter, align signals using cross-correlation with a reference trace before averaging or reconstruction to preserve sharp axial resolution.
preprocessing.software: Cross-correlation tools in MATLAB/Python; some DAQ systems include hardware-level jitter compensation.

preprocessing.description: Average repeated acquisitions at each position to reduce random noise (SNR ∝ √N). Apply dynamic range compression (e.g., log or gamma scaling) for visualization while preserving quantitative information in the linear domain for analysis.
preprocessing.software: Standard numerical libraries and image-processing packages (MATLAB, Python, ImageJ/Fiji).

steps.title: 3D reconstruction
steps.description: Run the chosen reconstruction algorithm on preprocessed RF data to obtain a 3D map of p_0(r) or μ_a(r). For routine work, start with filtered back-projection or k-space time-reversal; for challenging limited-view data, consider model-based iterative reconstruction with appropriate priors or regularization.

steps.title: Image enhancement and artifact assessment
steps.description: Inspect reconstructed volumes with linear and logarithmic intensity scaling; apply mild spatial filtering (e.g., Gaussian smoothing) to reduce noise while preserving structural detail. Identify apparent artifacts (streaks, rings, boundary echoes) and compare with expected patterns from the acquisition geometry.

steps.title: Segmentation and feature extraction
steps.description: Segment regions of high absorption (e.g., underdrawings, pigment-rich layers, cracks filled with absorbing material) using thresholding, region-growing, or machine-learning-based segmentation. Extract morphological descriptors (thickness, curvature, connectivity) relevant to heritage questions.

steps.title: Depth profiling and quantitative measurements
steps.description: Select lines or small ROIs and compute depth profiles of μ_a(z) to measure the depths and thicknesses of layers or hidden features. When calibrated, convert μ_a values into approximate absorber concentrations using known absorption coefficients; otherwise, interpret values qualitatively as relative contrasts.

steps.title: Spectroscopic unmixing (if multi-wavelength data are available)
steps.description: At each voxel, assemble the vector of μ_a(λ) values across wavelengths and model it as a linear combination of reference spectra for candidate chromophores. Solve the resulting linear or constrained least-squares problem to estimate the concentration maps for each pigment or binder. Validate assignments by comparing with independent spectroscopic measurements (Raman, FTIR, GC–MS, PAS).

steps.title: Multi-modal registration and interpretation
steps.description: Register PAT volumes to X-radiography, MA-XRF maps, OCT stacks, or high-resolution photographs. Use these combined datasets to interpret which features correspond to specific materials or interventions (e.g., original underdrawing versus later overpaint) and to construct coherent 3D models of the object’s stratigraphy and condition.

dataAnalysis.interpretationGuidelines: PAT volumes represent spatial maps of optical absorption coefficient μ_a(r). Bright regions correspond to strong absorbers (e.g., carbon-based underdrawings, dark pigments, iron-gall inks), while dim regions correspond to weakly absorbing materials (e.g., lead white in NIR, many binders, voids). Because PAT is sensitivity-weighted by both μ_a and the local fluence Φ, absolute quantitative interpretation requires calibration or modeling of fluence; in many heritage applications, PAT is used qualitatively or semi-quantitatively to locate and compare features rather than to provide absolute concentrations. Depth coordinates must be interpreted with knowledge of the assumed sound speed and potential heterogeneities; cross-checking with phantoms, OCT, or physical section measurements improves confidence. Whenever possible, PAT findings should be corroborated with complementary techniques (IRR, X-radiography, MA-XRF, Raman, FTIR, PAS) to assign specific materials and to distinguish true subsurface structures from artifacts.

primaryUseCases: Visualization of carbon-based and other absorbing underdrawings beneath opaque or highly scattering paint and ground layers
Detection of pentimenti and hidden compositional changes (painted-over figures, repositioned elements) at depths up to several millimeters
Three-dimensional mapping of pigment and absorber distributions in polychrome sculpture and painted wooden objects
Non-invasive assessment of internal wood structure, including cracks, insect galleries, delaminations, and moisture gradients
Localization of hidden inscriptions, undertexts, and palimpsests where absorbing inks or pigments are present beneath overlying material
Monitoring of conservation treatments such as consolidant or moisture penetration in porous substrates

materialTypes.material: Easel paintings on canvas or panel
materialTypes.notes: Particularly powerful for detecting underdrawings and hidden layers beneath lead-rich or strongly scattering paint where IR reflectography fails; depth reach is typically a few millimeters.
Enables 3D mapping of pigment layers and internal wood structure; wood’s relatively low NIR attenuation can permit imaging several millimeters to centimeters into the support.
Well suited for detecting cracks, voids, insect damage, and moisture distributions in panel paintings and architectural elements without destructive sampling.

Iron-gall and carbon-based inks provide strong absorption contrast; the thinness of substrates allows high axial resolution, but careful fluence control and mechanical support are essential to avoid damage.
Can reveal hidden patterns or stains if they produce sufficient absorption contrast; strong scattering and low absorption may limit depth and SNR.
High scattering and low optical absorption in many unpigmented mineral materials restrict PAT performance; painted or stained surfaces with absorbing pigments offer better prospects.

caseStudies.title: Revealing carbon underdrawing beneath opaque lead white in a 17th-century Dutch painting
caseStudies.institution: Delft University of Technology & Mauritshuis (The Hague)
caseStudies.objectType: Oil on canvas portrait attributed to the Rembrandt workshop, with extensive lead white impasto obscuring potential underdrawing
caseStudies.researchQuestion: Can PAT reveal carbon-based underdrawing lying hundreds of micrometers beneath dense lead white paint layers that are opaque to conventional infrared reflectography?
caseStudies.methodology: A custom PAT system using a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser with OPO tuned to 800 nm (10 ns pulses, ~15 mJ at the painting surface, 10 Hz) illuminated a 50×60 mm region of the face. A 5 MHz, 128-element linear ultrasound array in gel–membrane contact acquired RF data on a 0.5 mm raster grid, with 20 pulse averages per position. Data were reconstructed using k-Wave time-reversal with an assumed sound speed of 1800 m/s (optimized using calibration phantoms). The resulting 3D absorption volume (100×120×50 voxels, ~0.5×0.5×0.05 mm³) was compared with X-radiography, IR reflectography, and cross-section microscopy.
caseStudies.keyFindings: PAT revealed a network of high-absorption linear features at depths of 0.3–0.8 mm beneath the surface corresponding to a carbon-based underdrawing. These lines matched expected anatomical features (eyes, nose, mouth) and were invisible in both visible light and IR reflectography due to the opacity of the overlying lead white. Depth profiling showed the underdrawing located near the interface between the ground and the first paint layers, with depth estimates in good agreement (within ~0.1 mm) with micro-sampled cross-sections. X-radiography showed strong Pb signals in the overpaint but no direct evidence of carbon. The combined PAT–X-ray–IRR analysis clarified the painting’s stratigraphy and confirmed that the underdrawing belonged to the original composition rather than to later retouching.
caseStudies.significance: This study demonstrated, for the first time, that PAT can non-invasively image carbon-based underdrawings through millimeter-scale, highly scattering lead white paint where IR reflectography fails. It established PAT as a complementary modality to X-radiography and MA-XRF for investigating complex paint stratigraphies and informed decisions about cleaning and attribution in high-value old master paintings.

complementaryTechniques.rationale: X-ray radiography is highly sensitive to dense, high-Z pigments such as lead white and vermilion but is largely insensitive to carbon-based underdrawings or low-Z organic materials. PAT, in contrast, highlights optical absorption from both inorganic and organic species. Combining X-radiography and PAT enables discrimination between dense overpaints and underlying carbon-rich features.

Macro X-ray fluorescence (MA-XRF) provides element-specific surface or near-surface maps (Pb, Hg, Fe, Cu, Zn). PAT adds depth-resolved absorption maps. Registering MA-XRF and PAT volumes enables linking elemental distributions to depth-resolved chromophore maps, improving identification of pigments and stratigraphy.

Infrared reflectography is the established tool for underdrawing detection and is relatively fast and widely available. PAT is particularly valuable when IRR fails due to overlying opaque or highly scattering layers. A typical workflow is to use IRR for broad surveys and reserve PAT for targeted, problematic areas.

Optical coherence tomography provides micrometer-scale resolution of the top 1–2 mm of transparent or semi-transparent layers (varnish, glazes, some grounds). PAT extends the depth range to several millimeters with coarser resolution. Combining OCT and PAT yields a multi-scale view of surface and subsurface structures.

Photoacoustic spectroscopy (PAS) offers high-sensitivity 1D depth profiling and spectral discrimination of chromophores at a single location. PAT provides 2D/3D spatial context. Using PAS to determine optimal wavelengths and spectral signatures, and PAT to map their distribution, allows more robust interpretation.

Raman spectroscopy provides highly specific molecular identification at or near the surface but is limited in depth and can be hampered by fluorescence. PAT, which relies on absorption rather than Raman scattering, can probe deeper and is less affected by fluorescence. Raman and PAT together can link surface molecular identifications to deeper 3D distributions.

standardCombinations.name: PAT + X-radiography + MA-XRF for stratigraphic analysis
standardCombinations.workflow: 1) Acquire X-radiographs to map high-Z pigment distribution and structural features (cracks, nails, fills). 2) Perform MA-XRF scanning to obtain quantitative elemental maps of Pb, Hg, Fe, Cu, Zn, and other relevant elements at or near the surface. 3) Acquire a PAT volume over selected regions to obtain depth-resolved absorption maps. 4) Co-register the three datasets using fiducial marks or features visible in all modalities. 5) Interpret the combined data to reconstruct a 3D stratigraphic model: for example, differentiating original Pb white paint layers (with underlying carbon underdrawing in PAT and Pb signal in XRF) from later zinc white overpaints (Zn-rich in XRF, lacking underlying PAT signal).
standardCombinations.rationale: No single technique provides complete information about composition and structure in complex heritage objects. X-radiography excels at detecting dense materials, MA-XRF reveals elemental composition near the surface, and PAT adds volumetric absorption contrast for organics and inorganics. Their combination yields a powerful, non-destructive analysis of stratigraphy and can reduce the need for invasive sampling.
standardCombinations.exampleApplication: Authentication and condition assessment of a heavily restored 18th-century panel painting: X-radiography reveals extensive Pb- and Fe-rich overpaint; MA-XRF identifies zinc white retouching and original vermilion/orpiment layers; PAT shows that carbon underdrawing exists only beneath the original paint zones and not beneath modern zinc-based overpaints, supporting a distinction between original and later interventions.

advantages: Provides true 3D, depth-resolved maps of optical absorption in turbid media with millimeter-scale penetration and 100 μm–mm resolution
Combines optical contrast (sensitivity to pigments and organics) with ultrasonic propagation (reduced scattering and robust depth encoding)
Enables detection of underdrawings and hidden features beneath opaque or strongly scattering paint layers where IR reflectography fails
Allows non-invasive assessment of internal structures in wood and other supports without the need for sampling or X-ray radiation
Supports spectroscopic imaging (multi-wavelength PAT) for chemical contrast and pigment/binder discrimination
Integrates naturally with existing ultrasound hardware and reconstruction frameworks, benefiting from advances in biomedical PAT
limitations: High capital and operating cost compared to many other heritage imaging tools (IRR, visible reflectography, basic X-radiography)
Significant system complexity, requiring expertise in laser safety, acoustics, reconstruction algorithms, and heritage science
Acquisition times can be long (tens of minutes to hours for high-resolution 3D volumes), limiting throughput for large collections
Spatial resolution (∼100 μm–1 mm) is lower than that of OCT or microscopy and may not resolve extremely fine features
Depth penetration is ultimately limited by optical attenuation; very dense or highly scattering surface layers may prevent access to deeper structures
Acoustic coupling (water or gel) can be challenging for some objects, particularly large or highly sensitive paintings and textiles
As of 2025, PAT for heritage applications remains largely in the research domain, with limited commercial availability and standardized protocols
advantagesLimitations.whenToUse: Best employed when conventional methods (especially IR reflectography and X-radiography) provide incomplete information about subsurface absorbers, when depth-resolved knowledge of pigment or underdrawing distribution is crucial for interpretation or treatment planning, and when the institutional infrastructure can support advanced imaging campaigns. PAT is particularly promising for investigating underdrawings beneath opaque or complex paint stratigraphies, for mapping internal structures in wood panels, and for research projects that justify the investment in specialized equipment.
advantagesLimitations.whenNotToUse: PAT is not the first-line tool when surface-sensitive methods (IRR, OCT, Raman, FTIR, MA-XRF) can already answer the research question, when only very fine surface detail (<10–20 μm) is required, when budget or infrastructure cannot support high-cost, high-complexity systems, or when the object cannot be safely coupled to a water/gel medium or transported to a suitable facility. In such cases, alternative non-contact or lower-cost imaging methods may be preferable.

timeline.event: Alexander Graham Bell reports the photoacoustic effect (sound generation by modulated light)
timeline.significance: Provides the physical basis for all photoacoustic and optoacoustic techniques, though practical imaging would only emerge decades later.

timeline.event: Development of modern photoacoustic theory and early biomedical imaging demonstrations
timeline.significance: Work by Rosencwaig, Gersho, Tam, and others established the thermal diffusion model and showed the feasibility of photoacoustic imaging in tissues and solids.

timeline.event: Rapid growth of biomedical PAT, including small-animal and preclinical systems
timeline.significance: Optical-resolution and acoustic-resolution PAT systems demonstrated high-resolution vascular imaging, functional oxygenation mapping, and cancer detection, driving advances in lasers, arrays, and reconstruction algorithms.

timeline.event: First applications of PAT to cultural heritage objects
timeline.significance: Research groups began adapting biomedical PAT systems to image paintings, sculptures, and wood, demonstrating subsurface pigment and structural imaging and introducing PAT to the heritage science community.

timeline.event: Emergence of dedicated heritage PAT prototypes and high-profile case studies
timeline.significance: High-impact studies (e.g., underdrawing detection beneath lead white) have highlighted PAT’s unique capabilities and spurred efforts to develop more compact, user-friendly systems for cultural heritage use.

historicalDevelopment.currentStateOfArt: As of the mid-2020s, photoacoustic tomography for cultural heritage is a rapidly evolving research area with a small but growing number of dedicated systems worldwide. Most installations are custom-built in collaboration between physics/engineering laboratories and museums or conservation institutes. There is not yet a widely available commercial PAT instrument tailored specifically for heritage work, but lessons learned from biomedical PAT are being translated into this domain. Ongoing research focuses on improving portability, reducing acquisition times, integrating PAT with other imaging modalities, refining quantitative reconstruction in heterogeneous media, and establishing standardized protocols for safe and effective use with artworks.

costAnalysis.capitalEquipment: $200,000–$1,000,000 depending on laser type, array configuration, and level of automation. High-end tunable OPO-based systems with large arrays and GPU clusters are at the upper end of this range; simpler, single-wavelength systems using clinical ultrasound hardware and compact lasers can be built closer to the lower end.
costAnalysis.annualMaintenance: $20,000–$60,000 for laser servicing, transducer maintenance, DAQ and computer support, and general laboratory overheads. Laser flashlamp replacement and optical alignment are recurring costs; transducer arrays typically have multi-year lifetimes but may require occasional repair.
costAnalysis.consumables: Ultrasound gel and coupling media, deionized/degassed water, optical components (beam dumps, filters), and phantom materials. Annual consumables costs are modest compared to capital and staffing costs (order of $1,000–$5,000 per year).
costAnalysis.perSampleCost: When accounting for staff time, equipment depreciation, and consumables, a single comprehensive 3D PAT session on a heritage object may cost on the order of $500–$2,000. Costs decrease when multiple objects are imaged in a single campaign and when the system is integrated into a regularly scheduled research or conservation program.

hazards: High-peak-power Class 3B/4 laser radiation, with potential for serious eye or skin injury if not properly controlled
Electrical hazards associated with laser power supplies, high-voltage components, and high-speed DAQ electronics
Mechanical and ergonomic risks associated with moving heavy equipment and objects, as well as with water or gel handling
Potential for unintended heating or mechanical stress in sensitive materials if fluence limits are exceeded, particularly for fragile or highly absorbing pigments
safetyEquipment: Laser safety eyewear matched to the laser wavelength(s) and power levels
Beam enclosures, interlocked doors, and warning lights for Class 4 laser operation
Appropriate personal protective equipment (gloves, lab coats, non-slip footwear) when handling coupling media and heavy components
Spill containment and clean-up materials for water and gel
regulatoryCompliance: Compliance with ANSI Z136.1 (or equivalent national standards) for safe use of lasers, including training, administrative controls, and engineered safety measures
Adherence to institutional safety policies for high-voltage equipment and for the use of water near electrical devices
Documentation of risk assessments and mitigation strategies for each heritage object, particularly when coupling fluids or higher fluence levels are used

emergingDevelopments: Development of compact, portable PAT systems using high-repetition-rate diode or fiber lasers and lightweight ultrasound arrays for in-situ heritage work
All-optical PAT detection using interferometric or speckle-based methods that do not require direct contact or immersion, enabling truly non-contact subsurface imaging
Integration of PAT with OCT, structured-illumination microscopy (SIM), and MA-XRF into multimodal platforms that provide co-registered structural, chemical, and functional information
Real-time or near-real-time PAT reconstruction using dedicated GPU hardware and optimized algorithms, enabling interactive scanning and on-the-fly decision-making during conservation
Standardization of protocols, calibration phantoms, and data formats to facilitate comparison between laboratories and long-term archiving of PAT datasets
aiMlIntegration: Machine-learning-based reconstruction that accelerates or replaces iterative solvers, enabling high-quality images from sparse or noisy data
Automated detection and segmentation of underdrawings, cracks, and other features of interest using convolutional neural networks trained on annotated PAT datasets
Data-driven spectral unmixing of multi-wavelength PAT volumes to identify and quantify pigments and binders, even in the presence of overlapping spectra and noise
Use of deep-learning models to estimate spatially varying sound speed and attenuation from raw or reconstructed data, improving depth accuracy and compensating for heterogeneities
Interactive tools that combine PAT with other modalities in a unified visualization and analysis environment for conservators and art historians
